competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: fit Christmas tree-shaped polygons into the smallest square box for configurations of 1-200 trees. Score = sum of (side_length^2 / n) for all n. Lower is better.

The tree shape is a 15-vertex polygon with specific dimensions: trunk (0.15 wide, 0.2 tall), base tier (0.7 wide), middle tier (0.4 wide), top tier (0.25 wide), tip at y=0.8. Trees can be rotated 0-360 degrees.

Key optimizer: bbox3 - a C++ program using complex number vector coordination, fluid dynamics-inspired movement, hinge pivot, density gradient flow, and global boundary tension. Run with parameters -n (iterations) and -r (radius/range).

Rotation optimization: After placing trees, rotate the entire configuration to minimize bounding box side length. Uses scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar with bounds (0.001, 89.999) on convex hull points.
Overlap detection uses Shapely library with STRtree for efficient spatial queries. Collision = intersects but not touches. Must validate no overlaps before submission.

Multi-phase optimization strategy: Phase A (short 2-min runs to find promising n,r params), Phase B (10-min runs on top candidates), Phase C (20-min long runs on best few). Always keep best submission and revert on regression.
